ast.logging

Class LogFactory

  • java.lang.Object
    • ast.logging.LogFactory

  • public abstract class LogFactory
extends java.lang.Object
    Factory for creating Log instances, with discovery and configuration features similar to that employed by standard Java APIs.

    Loggers are organized into a naming hierarchy based on their dot separated names. Thus a.b.c is a child of a.b. The following properties are supported to configure the behavior of loggers:

    • ast.simplelog.rootLevel - Default logging detail level for all instances. Must be one of (all, debug (most detailed), info, warn, error (least detailed) or none). If not specified, defaults to info.
    • ast.simplelog.level.xxxxx - Logging detail level for an instance named xxxxx. If not specified, the parent's logging detail level is used.
    • ast.simplelog.showTimeUnit - The time unit to be used in the output messages. Must be one of (nanoseconds, microseconds, milliseconds, seconds, minutes, days, or hours). If not specified, time is not showed.

    Example: java -Dast.simplelog.rootLevel=error -cp build/classes/:lib/ast-protocols-1.3.1.jar ast.practica3.Main would set the logging level to error, thus neither showing debug, info nor warn levels

    • Method Detail

      • getFactory

        public static LogFactory getFactory()

        Construct (if necessary) and return a LogFactory instance, using the following ordered lookup procedure to determine the name of the implementation class to be loaded.

        1. The ast.logging.LogFactory system property. Its value is the fully qualified name of the implementation class.
        2. The Service Discovery mechanism (as detailed in the JAR specification), to determine the classname. The Services API will look for the classname in the file META-INF/services/ast.logging.LogFactory in jars available to the runtime.
        3. Fall back to a default implementation class (SimpleLogFactory).

        NOTE - In a multi-threaded environment it is possible that two different instances will be returned for the same classloader environment.

      • getInstance

        public Log getInstance(java.lang.Class clss)
        Convenience method to derive a name from the specified class and call getInstance(String) with it.
        Parameters:
        clss - Class for which a suitable Log name will be derived

      • getInstance

        public abstract Log getInstance(java.lang.String name)
        Construct (if necessary) and return a Log instance, using the factory's current set of configuration attributes. NOTE - Depending upon the implementation of the LogFactory you are using, the Log instance you are returned may or may not be returned again on a subsequent call with the same name argument.
        Parameters:
        name - Logical name of the Log instance to be returned (the meaning of this name is only known to the underlying logging implementation that is being wrapped)
        See Also:
        getInstance(Class)

      • getLog

        public static Log getLog(java.lang.Class clss)
        Convenience method to return a named logger, without the application having to care about factories.
        Same as getFactory().getInstance(clss).
        Parameters:
        clss - Class from which a log name will be derived
        See Also:
        getFactory()

      • getLog

        public static Log getLog(java.lang.String name)
        Convenience method to return a named logger, without the application having to care about factories.
        Same as getFactory().getInstance(name).
        Parameters:
        name - Logical name of the Log instance to be returned (the meaning of this name is only known to the underlying logging implementation that is being wrapped)
        See Also:
        getFactory(), getLog(Class)
